div.p: A DISCOURSE CONCERNING THE Fitnesse of the Posture NECESSARY TO BE USED IN TAKING THE Bread and Wine AT THE SACRAMENT.
By Edward Peyton, Knight and Barronet.

div.head: A DISCOVRSE Concerning the Fitnesse of the Posture necessary to be used in taking the Bread and Wine at the Sacrament.
div.p:
THough there hath clapsed a long time since your denying me the Sacrament, standing at the time of administring it, affirming that you had taken an Oath not to administer it to any but did kneel, though I did kneel before and after: yet all this time you should (to a man of my fashion) have had the manners, by letter, to have given me satisfaction, being Curate, and your duty: I will not omit mine; you shall have my reason. I did stand with just ground; wherefore I produce this ensuing Discourse to prove, you ought not to have denied me standing, at the time of giving of the Sacrament to me. If you say at the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 you were commanded by the Bishop or his Ordinarie so to doe; I answer, they had no power without the Parliament. But you will say, it is in the common Book of Prayers commanded, which is confirmed
by Parliament. I answer; It is not: for it is not said, you must kneel at the Sacrament, in the Rubrick, but make your Confession humbly kneeling on your knees. But you will say, you have a Canon for it: But I answer, It is not confirmed by Act of Parliament; therefore unlawfull, and cannot be imposed: for the Divines in this time, appointed by the Lords, would have a Rubrick touching the kneeling, which argueth it was not commanded before by Parliament See the sixteenth consideration upon the Common-Prayer book.. Wheras they say, that every one might kneel, that is (say they) comply, with all humility, with the prayer which the Minister makes, which is the Confession of our sinnes, that I grant; but not at the words of Administration, to wit, at the immediate taking of the Bread, and Wine: and the direction before these words was not in the Common Prayer Book of Edward the sixth, nor Queen Elizabeth; but put in since, as Master White in his His Speech in Parliament. Speech hath rightly affirmed.

What would you have me kneel to? If you say, to God, why did not Christ, and his Disciples, when he took, administred, and they received, kneel? If you say, to things administred: I answer, it is a creature, we ought not to kneel to a creature from the second Commandement. Then you make the things administred, God; if it be to the Minister, it is Idolatry: Acts 11. If it be to the Bread and Wine represented, you joyne with the Papists, to make it Christs body, and blood: If you say it is a Prayer, then examine it. Wherefore I will repeat the words: The body of our Lord Iesus Christ, which was given for thee; preserve thy body and soule to eternall life; take this in remembrance
that Christ died for thee, and feed on him in thy heart by thanksgiving: the other for the Blood is the same: is this a Prayer?

No Administration quatenus an Administration is a Prayer; and if I must kneel, why doe you not kneel, if it be a Prayer? But it is not a Prayer, but a good wish, counsell, and direction to the Receiver; for then the words should have beene, I pray God preserve thy body and soule to eternall life: you did not desire the people to preserve my body and soule, which is blasphemy: before, for preparation, and after for a blessing, I ought necessarily; and if I take the body and blood in remembrance Christ died for me, it is a Meditation, and not properly a Prayer; and after Meditation Prayer is needfull, and not before to perfect Meditation. If it be to Christ, why is the word Remembrance put in; I cannot remember a thing present. Pag. 132. My Lord of York in his holy Table, confesseth the gesture Christ had when he gave the holy Supper, was a Table gesture; which is (I say) mathematicall and perfect, and admits no alteration, for we ought to follow Christ in all things: for the Scripture saith, he is a perfect patterne, and shepherd of our soules. But (loving friend) these are but venies, I pray give me leave to play at sharp with you: wherefore, as a Champion, I enter the lists, and desire you friendly to look to your selfe: the first weapon I will encounter you with is the holy Scripture.

That gesture is best which is used of the Apostles, Eph. 5.1. 1 Cor. 11. 1 Tim. 16. 2 Thes. 3.7. but the Apostles used this gesture, yea Christ; therefore it is the best gesture: they sate downe, Math. 26.20. Mark 14.18. the word in the originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the new Interpreters
translate it, occubuit; the old, discumbebat,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; the new, cum Apostoli accubuissent; the old illis discumbentibus, Luke 22.14.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , discubuit, accubuit, which translated is, sate downe: and John the beloved Disciple of Christ is said, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , accumbens in sinu Iesu, sitting did lean upon the breast of Christ. This gesture is for feasts and banquets, saith Tremelius, Ioseph Scaliger,
Emend. temporum. and Beza upon the place; the same with our sitting at supper, when no other Scripture proveth positively other gesture in the Lords Supper, but that which answereth our sitting at feasts; as in the miracle of five loves and two fishes, which was a feast Luke 9.17.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , discubuerant, all sate downe; it is unlawfull to use other. Sitting is not indifferent, but necessary from the example of Christ, in which gesture we please God, and ought to doubt of kneeling, which is not commanded by God. Of which gesture, saith Calvin
Iust. l. 4. c. 17 sect. 35. at the end of the vers. against the Papists with all their cogitations, they ought not to observe, not to kneel, to adore the Sacrament, who securely may receive the Sacrament without adoration, not kneeling; for the Apostles did not prostrate themselves and adore it, but sate downe, took, and eat.
Bullinger Decad p. 461. all the section. Who can use a better gesture than Christ the high Priest of the Catholike Church, saith Bullinger? Christ used a gesture most necessary for all Churches, saith
Systema theolog. pag 465 the end of the verse. Kikerman: the reverence of the Sacrament is to be taken from the word of God, saith
Exam. Con. part 2 pag. 35. Chemnitius: kneeling was never used in three hundred yeares after Christ, say the Centuries
Holian Con. 4. l. 4. c 26. • 8. in the Epilogue to the 4 Centuary Tertullian proveth from an antient custome in the Primitive Church,
De Corona militis. namely on every Sunday from Easter
to Whitsuntide none should kneel on the Lords day, which custome hitherto we enjoy, saith Tertullian. So is the Nicene Councell, Canon 20. that they should stand on the Lords day, and pray to the Lord, rendring their vowes: which Canon taxeth the Montanists Centu. 4. l. 2. c. 10. of heresie and superstition, which the Fathers would abolish, the yeare 327 saith Hosiander; Basial the yeare 386
Lib. de Sp. sancto. in whose time he affirmeth and defendeth, it was the custome of the Apostles; and rendreth divers reasons, that they never received, but stood in the Church from Easter to Whitsuntide: now for to think that in three hundred yeares and more they never received the Sacrament from Easter to Whitsuntide, is absurd, when all Ecclesiasticall Writers are plaine, they received in the Primitive Church every Lords day, and never kneeled at the Sacrament. The yeare 140
Eusebius Cron. l. 17. cap. Graci 19. Latin. 18. Damasus Bishop of Antioch writing to Pope Xistus 2, saith in giving thanks they said Amen, and stood at the Table, with their hands took the holy bread. You shall finde it in the Translation of Iohn Iames Grineus, not in Iohn Christopher, which is castrated of the Papists. Cent 3. pag. 133. This custome, say the Centuries, was in use in many Churches. I pray what correspondency or proportion hath kneeling with the Sacrament, either with the end or use of it? Nor concurreth it with the intimate intention of the heart; for the end is to conforme us in grace; what conformation hath kneeling, unlesse to conforme us in Transubstantiation, which is heresie by our Church? In the beginning of Queen Elizabeth a reason before the Rubrick was set downe, that they should not kneel in respect of avoiding the heresie of Transubstantiation,
and Consubstantiation, which since is put out to sympathize with Papists; and the use is to receive the body and blood of Christ by faith, which is taken away by kneeling, affirming Christs presence: we beleeve he is in heaven, not bodily on earth: if on earth, his body is a Monster; for in heart reverence to the Sacrament kneeling is adoration, for adoration is in heart and gesture; for the Elements of Bread and Wine represent his Humanity, not his Deity, which makes it an absurdity to kneel to the Humanity, a Creature. Is not this a plaine confirmation of the Papists, and Lutherans: for Christ fell downe on his face and prayed Math. 26.29 a gesture only due for Prayer: Mark. 14.35 he fell on the earth and prayed: Luke 22.41. upon his knees and prayed: Psal. 95.6. we bend our knees to the Lord after the example of Elias. Daniel prayed thrice a day on his knees: Psal. 95. David saith, let us fall downe and kneel to the Lord which made us. Positively we are bound to pray to God on our knees, and wee are forbidden to kneel in the example of Christ and his Apostles in the Sacrament.

p.hi: To bend the knee to a Creature, Propos. in divine norship, is Idolatry.
But to bend the knee at the Sacrament, Assump. is to bend the knee to a Creature;

div.p: Ergo, Conclus. To bend at the Sacrament is Idolatry.

The Proposition is proved Exod. 30.5. from the second Commandement: In which two things are forbidden, to make the Image of any thing in heaven, of the starres; in earth, of men and beasts; under the earth, fishes of the sea: and in the disjunctive bowing to Creatures, Sun, moon, Starrs, Men, Beasts, Vegetables,
Mineralls, &c. And to kneel to them is equally forbidden, as adoration, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 of Master Perkins is defined,
(a) Aurea Calena 2. Com. pre. hib. 5. God is worshipped with the intention of the heart: From hence may be gathered (saith hee) That Ceremonies, Col. 2.23. 1 Sam. 13.9, 10 13. and bending the knee at the Sacrament is to worship God otherwise than hee hath commanded; and therefore it is Idolatry: So that to reverence the Sacrament, which is a Creature, is forbidden. Argum. 2.
Ibid. Pet. 2. com. prohib. 8. Corruptions saith (Perkins) and humane Traditions are forbidden; But bending the knees at the Sacrament, &c. is a humane Tradition, proved before out of divers Authors; Ergo, Bending the knee at the Sacrament is forbidden. Also saith Perkins,
Ibid. prohib. 8. praecept. 2. The worship of God is polluted when any thing is added to the Scripture or diminished. Christ used in the Sacrament the gesture of a Banquet, not that of Adoration and prayer: and so wee frame our Conclusion implicitly, from the perfect example of Christ.
And as for the Assumption (they say) they doe reverence the Actions of the Sacrament, not the Sacrament it selfe.

To reverence religiously the Sacrament, the things belonging thereto, or the actions, more than we ought, is Idolatry; But to bend the knee at the actions, or to the things in the Sacraments, or at the Sacraments, religiously, is to reverence the actions, or the Sacraments, &c. more than wee ought; Ergo, Religiously to reverence the Sacraments, the things in the Sacraments, or the actions, more than wee ought, is Idolatry.

Wee will fortifie the major from Mr. Perkins,
Fraecept: probib. 9. who saith, A religious reverence of the Creature is forbidden in the second Commandement, because it is greater than God commands.

I will strengthen the minor; for bending the knee in the Sacrament is a more humble gesture than Christ used or his Apostles: For it is an assured truth, If the Apostles did not bend the knee, Christ being present, much lesse when Christ is absent: we ought not to bend the knee unlesse wee will hold with the Papists that Christ is corporally present; for no body can be present in so many places, where the Sacrament is administred. Acts 10.25. Tremel. • i • l. The bending to the actions is unlawfull, the intention of adoration being wanting: (Tremelius.) Cornelius fell at Peters feet and worshipped, (Beza.)
Annot. 26. on the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Acts 10. Falling at the feet of Peter, worshipped: From whence hee inferrs, (in the same place) That religious bending the knee is onely to God; to give it to civill Ministers of the Word is dangerous. Did Cornelius think the religious worship that was due to God might bee transferred to Peter? no truly; but strook with so great a reverence of the servant of God, hee kept no mean; For it is not easie to hold a moderation in reverence and adoration, Beza. Apoc. 13.19. Bez. inter. Iohannes procidit ante pedes Angeli ut adoraret eum: the old Interpretation, Cecidit ante pedes ut adoraret:
Annot. c. 11. v. 10. Iunius on this Verse saith, Wee must abstaine from divine worship to creatures; of which religious kneeling is one. Apoc. 22.8, 9. Iohn fell down and worshipped; See thou doe it not (saith the Angell;) I am thy fellow servant, worship God. Therefore to kneel down to the action at the Sacrament, which is divine honour, and a Creature, is forbidden: For if wee doe it to Christ as a
Creature and Man, it is unlawfull; for the Papists deny the Deity is bread or blood, Christ being really there; which heresie wee confirme by our kneeling to it. Wee will use the Arguments of the Papists to prove this Truth; namely, what their Champion Bellarmine is wont to maintain;
De • uchar. l. 2. c. 18. p. 619. If kneeling at the Sacrament may be without sin, as the Calvinists say, then it is not Idolatry to kneel before Images: and the observation is not to be omitted. And Christ Luke 22.19
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , when he brake the Bread, gave thanks, and gave it to his Disciples: which of the Fathers is
Cent. 2.99.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the Sacrament called from giving of thanks, and it is improper to give thanks kneeling; for that is not the fittest gesture. I will shew it from the example of Solomon Kings 8.54, 55. who ending his Prayers, stood up and gave thanks, because God heard his prayers kneeling is inconvenient, therefore it ought to be abolished. Wherefore S. Aug. saith,
Aug. Ep. 119 although Ceremonies have not open evill in themselves, notwithstanding because they are inconvenient to burthen the Church with humane presumptions, if they have not authority from holy Scripture, nor from Generall Councels, nor from the Universall Church, but from a doubtfull beginning, without all doubt they are to be cut off.

But some may object from
Ibidem
Augustine, a mutation in the Church is dangerous, which causeth an unfruitfull trouble. I answer them with Augustine and
Ibidem 1 Sam. 14. Peter Martyr, When Ceremonies cease to bee profitable without doubt they are to be removed.

Kneeling, because it is used of the Papists to adore Bread and Wine, is necessarily to be held unprofitable:
Ep. 86. d Causel. For Augustine holdeth Fasting indifferent on the
Sabbath, yet by reason of circumstance it may have some scandall, as of the Fast of the Manichees, hee holdeth it unlawfull. Besides, Bowing towards the East was long in use among the Fathers, yet Leo
Leo. serv. de nold. Dom. took away this antient Custome, because it was observed of Pagans in adoration of the Sun, and did obdurate them. For although it be supposed, Kneeling might be used in the beginning of Queen Elizabeths time, to reconcile us to the Papists, or rather to draw them to us; yet now it is not good, in this light of the Gospel, to harden the Papists hearts: For
Epist. 18. S. Augustine saith, What is untowardly done in the worship of God, ought to be amended, or not to be commanded. Wherefore I conclude with the before Sylogisme, When kneeling at the Sacrament is neither in the word of God comprehended, nor positively commanded, nor by consequence gathered, nor of Generall Councells commanded, nor of the Catholike Church, (but of the Carolicall) accustomed, yea of the Reformed Churches inhibited, or not used, except ours; and when it is a scandall and hardening to the Papists, and against the Nicene Councell in the Primitive Church, for these reasons deservedly it ought to be abolished in our Church: and you ought not to hinder me standing, which may be with as much reverence as kneeling.
